awd_titl_txt: CNS Core:Small: Attaining Multi-Terabit/sec Wireless Data Rates
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past two decades, even though considerable progress has been made in providing ubiquitous wireless connectivity, the actual data rates available today fall far short of what is required by next generation applications. Examples of such applications include immersive virtual reality (VR) that can enable remote surgery, instant and on-demand upgrades to the intelligence of self-driving vehicles to enhance safety, and real-time backup to the cloud of digital video data which has numerous commercial applications. All of these applications require extremely high wireless data rates that cannot be delivered by any of the present-day wireless technologies. This project explores the problem of utilizing the terahertz spectrum to provide these data rates. Unfortunately, this part of the radio spectrum suffers many impairments such as blockage and molecular absorption. This project will develop new methods to overcome these challenges by developing novel communication architectures and algorithms. The benefits to society are many including enabling true remote health care, enhancing safety of autonomous vehicles, and providing very high bandwidth wireless connections that can form the basis for a whole class of new applications in future generation wireless networks.

This proposal seeks to study how Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) techniques can be utilized at terahertz frequencies. Given the specific idiosyncrasies of terahertz propagation, the proposal will use measurements and modeling to address challenges arising from poor signal propagation. In addition, the proposal will develop novel optical and hybrid MIMO technologies for terahertz. The specific objectives for the research are: perform measurements to model Massive MIMO systems for terahertz; analyze MIMO performance given various types of channel impairments such as obstructed antennas and sub-optimal spacing; study optical-MIMO and hybrid MIMO for terahertz; using Matlab simulations and models demonstrate multi-terabit/sec communications. The eventual outcomes of this work will include terahertz models for MIMO, optical-MIMO and hybrid MIMO including a database of channel measurements. The project will also produce Matlab software to study different communication scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The goal of this project was to study the challenges in providing multi-terabit/sec datarate for wireless users by exploiting the terahertz frequemncy band. The terahertz frequency band extends from 100 GHz to 10 THz, though our focus was on frequencies up to 525 GHz. The terahertz band is mostly unused and the huge available spectrum makes it possible to support large numbers of users at high data rates. 

Unfortunately, the terahertz transmissions are easily blocked and some parts of the band are also absorbed in the atmosphere. Therefore, it is necessary to use MIMO (Multiple Input Multiple Output) to deliver high capacity. In this project, we used measurements conducted on two testbeds to evaluate the challenges faced by MIMO at terahertz frequencies. In the measurements, we considered cases when the two radios have a direct line of sight between them, as well as cases when the only communicating path was a reflected one. We also conducted measurements for different MIMO antenna arrays that had different relative orientations. Finally, we measured the channel for the case when parts of the antenna were obscured.

Using our extensive measurements, we developed mathemtical models that explain the received signal. We noticed the sensitivity of the channel capacity to variations in distance - as the distance increases the capacity falls due to attenuation and due to the channel matrix becoming correlated. We also observed a new phenomena - the attenuation showed a periodicity with distance. On further onvestigation we discovered that this was caused due to the establishment of stationary waves between the transmit and receive antennas.

To address the problem of drop in capacity due to the channel becoming correlated, we experimented with non-uniform reflectors in order to create multiple reflections with slightly differing phase. We discovered some simple structures that ensure that the channel stays decorrelated with increasing distances. In practice, these types of inexpensive reflectors can be deployed on walls of rooms to both, enhance capacity, and to improve coverage (around obstacles).

Broader Impact:

The work we have conducted has resulted in several research publications and in the creation of an extensive online database of terahertz channel propagation measurements. These measurements are available to anyone for use in their own research. Thus the broad impact of our work on enhancing research in the community is significant. The PI also involved two graduate students in this work. At the start of the project these students had no know;edge of wireless communications since their expertise was in devices. However, after working on this project, they both now possess expert-level knowledge of wireless commucations at the physical layer. One of these two students will be graduating with her Ph.D. in Spring 2024. The PI has also involved high-school students in his work. One of these students went on to major in ECE at the University of California San Diego, anothert went on to join Northeastern University in CS, and a third is currently applying to colleges for the Fall 2024 term.
